technical-data.invention-title: METHODS FOR DEBLENDING OF SEISMIC SHOT GATHERS
SYSTÈMES ET PROCÉDÉS POUR SÉPARER DES GROUPEMENTS DE TIRS SISMIQUES

abstract.p: Methods to deblend seismic data from a plurality of sources and received by a plurality of sensors as shot gathers is disclosed. The deblending is performed by a Mutual Interdependence Analysis Method to separate contributions of different shots. Deblending is also performed by applying a measure of coherence in parallel data domains such as Common Shot Gather and Common Midpoint. Deblending is also is achieved by using the hyperbolic nature of seismic data in the common midpoint domain. Deblended signals are estimated and are applied to create a seismic image. Also, Bergman iteration based migration is applied directly on the blended seismic shot gathers without first deblending as an alternative method. The methods are applied in seismic imaging for exploration of natural resources. imaging for exploration of natural resources.

Methods to deblend seismic data from a plurality of sources and received by a plurality of sensors as shot gathers is disclosed. The deblending is performed by a Mutual Interdependence Analysis Method to separate contributions of different shots. Deblending is also performed by applying a measure of coherence in parallel data domains such as Common Shot Gather and Common Midpoint. Deblending is also is achieved by using the hyperbolic nature of seismic data in the common midpoint domain. Deblended signals are estimated and are applied to create a seismic image. Also, Bergman iteration based migration is applied directly on the blended seismic shot gathers without first deblending as an alternative method. The methods are applied in seismic imaging for exploration of natural resources. imaging for exploration of natural resources.

L'invention porte sur un système et sur des procédés qui permettent de séparer des données sismiques d'une pluralité de sources, qui sont reçues par une pluralité de capteurs sous la forme de groupements de tirs. La séparation est effectuée par un procédé d'analyse d'interdépendance mutuelle pour séparer des contributions de différents tirs. La séparation est également effectuée par l'application d'une mesure de cohérence dans des domaines de données parallèles, tels qu'un groupement de tirs communs et un point milieu commun. La séparation est également effectuée par l'utilisation de la nature hyperbolique de données sismiques dans le domaine de point milieu commun. Des signaux séparés sont estimés et sont appliqués pour créer une image sismique. Une migration fondée sur une itération de Bergman est également appliquée directement sur les groupements de tirs sismiques mélangés sans première séparation, à titre de variante de procédé. Les procédés sont appliqués dans l'imagerie sismique pour l'exploration de ressources naturelles.

CROSS REFERENCE TO RELATED APPLICATIONS
[0001] The present application claims the benefit of U.S. Provisional Patent Application Ser. No 61/476,530 filed on April 18, 2011, which is incorporated by reference herein in its entirety.
BACKGROUND

[0002] The present invention relates to deblending of blended data. More specifically, this invention relates to deblending of seismic data generated by semi-simultaneous sources and received by a plurality of sensors.

[0003] Conventional seismic surveys require that the time interval between two source shots (e.g. dynamite or vibrators on land, and air guns in marine survey) is sufficiently long to avoid interference between these shots. This makes seismic data acquisition time consuming. To reduce survey time, the number of shots is restricted to an acceptable minimum. It turns out that the spatial domain is poorly sampled.

[0004] Simultaneous sources/blended acquisition refers to having several sources in a single shot gather. Such a data acquisition scheme can reduce time in field surveys and efficiently provide versatile illumination and dense sampling geometry, thus offering cost saving and better seismic image quality.
[0005] Present day methods to deblend blended data can lead to unsatisfactory results if source interference is not adequately removed or diminished.

[0006] Accordingly, new and improved methods and systems to deblend blended data are required.

DESCRIPTION OF A PREFERRED EMBODIMENT

[0038] Simultaneous sources/blended acquisition refers to several sources in a single shot gather. This data acquisition scheme can reduce time in field surveys and efficiently provide versatile illumination and dense sampling geometry, thus offering cost saving and better seismic image quality. A snapshot illustrating the blended source wave field is shown in FIG. 1. Specifically, the measured data can be expressed as a MxExT matrix Pb, where M, E, and T denote, respectively, the number of receivers, the number of experiments (i.e., shot records), and the sample numbers in a trace. Using a blending matrix Γ to model the blending operation of different sources for each trace sample, the unblended data matrix P is related to Pb by:

Equation (1) states that the blended data is just a linear combination of each isolated shot, possibly with random delay among different shots. For a fixed trace sample t, each row and column of Pb represents, respectively, a receiver gather and a shot record. FIG. 1 shows a snapshot of a blended source wave field. Each semi-circle is a wave field from a single shot.

[0039] One objective of the present invention is to create high quality seismic images from the observed data Pb. A straightforward approach would be to directly apply the conventional migration methods, whose presumed inputs are P rather than Pb, to obtain the seismic image.
However, conventional processing does not account for the interfering nature of the blended data. Therefore, the results of this simple approach are generally not satisfactory. On the other hand, if one is able to estimate P from Equation (1), the source interference is removed; and then the conventional methods can be applied to improve the results. The estimation of P is referred to as deblending. Three methods are provided below in accordance with one or more aspects of the present invention to deblend Pb.

[0040] In most cases, the number of experiments E is much smaller than the number of different sources N, making Equation (1) highly underdetermined. Solving Equation (1) for P is ill-posed; and the model information in the source domain is difficult to exploit. Therefore, rather than trying to deblend Pb, one can directly seek the optimal image (in the sense of a certain metric, such as least square) of the subsurface model m that, after forward modeling of wave propagation L, satisfies the data fidelity
Pb ~ Lm.

[0041] To solve for m, one can consider employing metric-based migration directly from the blended sources, with model regularization in the image domain. This approach will be further expanded below.

[0042] In accordance with different embodiments of this invention, at least four novel approaches to handle seismic data with simultaneous sources will be provided. First, a mutual interdependence analysis (MIA) approach is provided to extract the signal of interest based on the concept of equal correlation. Different from the filtering based local processing, the correlation is calculated of each shot among different experiments. The shot separation can then be achieved as described in a section further below.

[0043] Second, the idea of enforcing coherence in both the common midpoint domain (CMP) and common shot gather (CSG) is introduced and can be used in accordance with an
aspect of this invention. CMP domain coherence is estimated via filtering based approaches. A mask indicating the signal contribution from different shots is generated, and then transferred to the CSG domain as an initial estimate that is subsequently refined through the CSG domain coherence measure. This process is further described in a section below. Other ways of performing this task are described later as well.

[0044] Thirdly, a hyperbola fitting method based on local image analysis is provided. A feature vector generated from a second moment matrix is associated with each pixel. In the CMP domain, these features are used to find the hyperbola that best fit the data, thus separating non-coherent signals. This process is further explained in a section below.

[0045] Finally, a fourth approach as formulated in a section below, aims directly at the seismic images without specific deblending. Preconditioned iterative migration is employed that is cast as an optimization problem and takes advantage of the model information. Bregman iteration is applied to solve the associated cost functional and to preserve weak signals. The preconditioner is implemented as a high pass filter and enables fast convergence of the iterations. The solution provided in accordance with an aspect of the present invention makes the iterative scheme computational practical and achieves better image quality.
[0046] MIA based deblending of seismic shot gathers

[0047] In the following section a deblending approach of seismic shot gathers in accordance with an aspect of the present invention will be further described. It is assumed that each blended shot gather can be modeled as an additive combination of N single shot recordings. Furthermore, each single shot recording is assumed to be present in multiple experiments. It is the intuition that this mutually present component is equally correlated with itself between experiments but uncorrected to other shot recordings in the blended shot gathers. In the following, mutual interdependence analysis will be described, the background
of the extraction of such mutual components and discuss how this method is applied to the seismic domain.
[0048] Background Of Mutual Independence Analysis

[0049] In previous work— Claussen, H., Rosea, J., Damper, R., 2009. "Generalized mutual interdependence analysis. " International Conference on Acoustics, Speech and Signal Processing.Taipei, Taiwan, pp. 3317-3320; Claussen, H., Rosea, J., Damper, R., 2008. "Mutual features for robust identification and verification. " International Conference on Acoustics, Speech and Signal Processing. Las Vegas, NV, pp. 1849-1852; and Claussen, H., Rosea, J., Damper, R., 2007. "Mutual interdependence analysis. " Independent Component Analysis and Blind Signal Separation, Springer- Verlag, Heidelberg, Germany, pp. 446-453, which is incorporated by reference — mutual interdependence analysis (MIA) has been developed and successfully used to extract complex representations, or " "mutual features", accounting for samples in the class. A mutual feature is a linear regression that is equally correlated with all samples of the input class. MIA, and its generalization (GMIA) have been shown to be related to statistical techniques such as canonical correlation analysis and Bayesian estimation. While common statistical signal processing approaches assume the number of inputs M to be much larger than their dimensionality D, MIA assumes M < D linearly independent inputs. It was shown that "mutual faces" extracted from the Yale database are illumination invariant, and obtain identification error rates of 7.4% in exhaustive leave -one -out tests. Also, "mutual speaker signatures" for text independent speaker verification achieve state-of-the-art equal error rates of 6.0% on the NTIMIT database. The effectiveness of the GMIA approach and its difference to ubiquitous signal processing methods, such as principal and independent component analysis, is exemplified in FIG. 2 on artificial data.
[0050] FIG. 2 illustrates comparison of results using various ubiquitous signal processing methods. Top left plot shows, for simplicity, an overlay of the first three of overall 20 inputs, which are all mixtures of a common component (top middle plot) and other interfering sources. The bottom plots show components obtained in an attempt to extract the common component, using the mean, principal component analysis (PCA) and independent component analysis (ICA). The components outlined for PCA and ICA are those that maximally correlate with the common component. The GMIA solution turns out to accurately represent the common component, as it is maximally correlated to it.

[0051] Below it is shown that MIA can be used to separate contributions of a single source from multi-experiment multi-shot seismic data. This could be a useful pre-processing step for exploiting blended shot data in a traditional seismic data analysis workflow.
[0052] MIA-Based Deblending Approach

Finally it is assumed that the timings and combinations of sources vary over experiments and are known.

[0064] CSG/CMP Coherence based deblending of seismic shot gathers

[0065] Alternatively to MIA, the coherence of shot gathers can be used for deblending. In this section it is further discussed how coherence is used in the literature to address blended shot gathers. Thereafter, using coherence parallel in different domains for deblending is provided.

[0066] Multi-shot seismic gathers are processed in particular input representations such as the common midpoint (CMP) domain to cancel the between-shot interference [see for instance Huo S., Luo Y., and Kelamis P., 2009. "Simultaneous sources separation via multi-directional vector-median filter", 79th Annual International Meeting, SEG, pp. 31-34]. For example, assume small random delay times between the K sources activated in each of the E experiments. The recorded data is initially available in the common shot gather (CSG) domain illustrated in FIG. 4. Note that the figure shows a snapshot where only one of the K sources is active. The data is then transferred e.g., to the CMP domain. Here, each column represents a sensor signal from possibly different experiments. While the CMP shot/receiver combinations result in a structured and coherent signal, the interfering shots result in non-coherent, random and localized distortions. Therefore, it is possible to utilize the information about randomness, localization and coherence to suppress the interference. Proposed methods separate into stacking and filter/layer-separation based approaches. It was shown that stacking can effectively suppress the random energy [see for instance: Hampson G., Stefani J., and Herkenhoff E. F., 2008. "Acquisition using simultaneous sources ", The Leading Edge, v. 27, no. 7, pp. 918-923]. However, noise suppression by stacking cancels the possibility to use powerful pre-stack migration approaches. On the other hand filter/layer-separation approaches
that utilize coherence include Radon transform based methods [see for instance: Akerberg P., Hampson G., Rickett J., Martin H. and Cole J., 2008. "Simultaneous source separation by sparse radon transform ", 78th Annual International Meeting, SEG, pp. 2801-2805; Spitz S., Hampson G., and Pica A., 2008. "Simultaneous source separation: a prediction-subtraction approach " , 78th Annual International Meeting, SEG, pp. 2811-2815] and the vector median filter approach as described in Huo S., Luo Y., and Kelamis P., 2009. "Simultaneous sources separation via multi-directional vector-median filter", 79th Annual International Meeting, SEG, pp. 31-34. The advantage of these approaches is that the following migration process can adopt the conventional methods to obtain an accurate image for subsequent interpretation.
[0067] In the following it is shown how deb lending can be improved by using coherence parallel in different input domains such as the CSG and CMP domain. The approach is illustrated in FIG. 4.
[0068] Assume the inputs of the deblending to be common source gathers from E experiments containing each K blended sources.

[0069] In a first step, the data is transferred to the CMP domain separately for shots with different arrival times. That is, first all CSGs are transferred to the CMP domain using the location and timing of the first arriving source. Second, the CSGs are transferred to the CMP domain using the location and timing of the second arriving shot and so on. Note that in this domain the interfering shots appear random as the data comes from multiple experiments with different shot combinations and random timings.

[0070] In a second step, the interfering shot contributions are detected using coherence based filtering such as the vector-median filter. This is described in, for instance, Huo S., Luo Y., and Kelamis P., 2009. "Simultaneous sources separation via multi-directional vector- median filter", 79th Annual International Meeting, SEG, pp. 31-34, which is incorporated
herein by reference. These contributions are marked dependent on their respective effect to the overall signal energy. The result of this marking is a map that represents the percentile contribution of each pixel to the signal and interference energy. This approach is performed for all CMP gathers of all K near simultaneous sources.
[0071] In a third step, the masks are transferred back to the CSG domain. They provide a first estimate for each pixel contribution to the different shots.

[0072] In a fourth step, these estimates are refined using the coherence of all shots in the CSG domain. It is the intuition that this additional dimension, in which different coherence information can be utilized, helps to improve the accuracy of the deblending result.

[0073] Finally, to resolve ambiguities, the steps can be iterated or additional domains can be selected that provide independent coherence measures, such as the common receiver or common offset domain. In accordance with an aspect of the present invention coherence is determined concurrently in at least two domains. In accordance with a further aspect of the present invention coherence is determined concurrently in at least three domains. Such domains include the Common Shot Gather, Common MidPoint Gather, Common Offset Gather and Common Detector Gather.

[0074] FIG. 4 illustrates simulated coherence based deblending that parallel uses coherence in different data representations such as the CSG and CMP domain. The two blended shot records are numbered by their time of arrival. The shots with the same number but from different experiments are transferred to the common midpoint domain. Coherence based filtering is performed resulting in masks that indicate the amount of energy per pixel that contributes to the interference or coherent structure. These masks are then transferred back to the CSG domain where they are refined using coherence.
[0075] As was stated above, in a first step, the data is transferred to the CMP domain separately for shots with different arrival times. That is, first all CSGs are transferred to the CMP domain using the location and timing of the first arriving source. Second, the CSGs are transferred to the CMP domain using the location and timing of the second arriving shot and so on. Note that in this domain the interfering shots appear random as the data comes from multiple experiments with different shot combinations and random timings.

[0076] Each column in the CMP gather represents a column from the CSG domain. Therefore, each point in this column can have energy contributions from all shots fired in the respective experiment in the CSG domain. Now referring to FIGs. 5 and 6 which identify an evaluated point x (500) and possible neighbors in a CMP domain in FIG. 6. For example, the currently evaluated point x in FIG. 5 can have energy contributions from shot#l and shot#2. Point 500 is also identified in FIG. 6 in the CMP domain. The question that the herein provided approach answers is: How much energy of the point x is from shot#l and how much energy is from shot#2? To solve this, the probability of the energy contribution from shot#l and shot#2 are first estimated separately. This is achieved by computing the histogram of the energies from all neighboring points in all analyzed domains. Such domains include Common Shot Gather, Common Mid Point Gather, Common Offset Gather and Common Detector Gather. Only neighboring points that relate to the physical constraints such as points on the lines of the normal move out preprocessed CMP, on the hyperbolic CSG etc. are considered. Furthermore, the histograms can include the energies of the neighboring points of the initial neighbors in all domains. In this way, a large number of related energy values are selected for an accurate computation of the histograms. Similar histograms are computed for all shots that were possibly contributing to the energy in x.
[0077] It is assumed that the energy contribution of the different shots is statistically independent. Thus, it is possible to compute the joint probability of the energy contributions from different shots by the product of the marginal distributions that were estimated by the histograms of energies of neighboring points as discussed above. The joint probability function is illustrated in FIG. 8. Note that only combination of energy contributions from different shots are possible that add to the total energy at the currently evaluated point x. In the example of two blended shots this constraint results into a line in the two dimensional energy pdf as shown in FIG. 8. The point 800 that fits this constraint and has the highest probability value is selected as the most likely split of the energies from different shots. FIG. 7 illustrates the steps of this approach.
[0078] The procedure from FIG. 7 is repeated for all data points. Thereafter, one can display exclusively the energy contributions from one of the sources and thus show the deblended result.

[0079] As an aspect of the present invention a neighborhood of datapoint to a first datapoint is defined herein below. The above procedure and method in one embodiment of the present invention is performed for a neighborhood of a first datapoint, which includes datapoints that are not directly neighboring the first datapoint.

[0080] One advantage of this deblending method in comparison to filtering used e.g., in the vector median filter, as described in Hou S., Luo Y., and Kelamis P., 2009. "Simultaneous sources separation via multi direction vector median filter", 79th Annual International Meeting, SEG, pp. 31-34, is that the energy from each pixel is split over the possible contributing shots rather than replaced with neighboring energy values. The approach provided herein as an aspect of the present invention takes into account that the sum of the energy contributions from the shots has to add to the energy value that was observed at this location. Also the energy
distributions of the neighboring points are considered rather than the simple median value and combining information from a plurality of domains are also considered, thus enabling a more robust result.

[0081] In one embodiment of the present invention one determines a coherence as described above concurrently in two or more domains. Based on the described analysis a processor can make the decision about a measure of coherence in a domain. In a further embodiment of the present invention a processor can make for each domain or for each mask a binary (yes or no) coherence decision. The processor in a next step collects all the binary coherence decisions and determines, for instance when in a majority of domains a coherence was determined, in a final decision if coherence was determined yes or no.

[0082] A neighboring point to a first datapoint in a transform domain such as a CMP domain in accordance with one aspect of the present invention is a datapoint that is directly adjacent to the first datapoint on a relevant axis. No intermediate datapoints are present between the neighboring point and the first datapoint.

[0083] In accordance with a further aspect of the present invention a neighborhood in a transform domain of the first datapoint is defined as a maximum range of intermediate datapoints between the first datapoint and what is called a neighborhood datapoint.

[0084] In accordance with yet a further aspect of the present invention the methods as described herein in accordance with one or more aspects of the present invention are applied to at least one datapoint in a neighborhood of a first datapoint, wherein the at least one datapoint is not a direct neighbor of the first datapoint.

[0085] A neighborhood of a first datapoint can then be defined as a range of points that includes the direct neighbors of a datapoint as well as the datapoints with at most 1 , 2, 3, 4, ....n intermediate datapoints between a point in the neighborhood and the first datapoint.
[0086] As discussed above, multiple filterMayer-separation approaches are used in the literature to address blended seismic shot gathers. In the following, we propose our own method for signal separation using local energy and hyperbola fitting.
[0087] Signal separation using local energy and hyperbola fitting

[0088] In this section a filer/layer-separation approach is provided that uses both local image analysis and the hyperbolic nature of seismic recordings in the common midpoint (CMP) domain. These concepts are successfully used in the literature. That is, the vector median filter approach, such as described in Huo S., Luo Y., and Kelamis P., 2009. "Simultaneous sources separation via multi-directional vector-median filter", 79th Annual International Meeting, SEG, pp. 31-34, which is incorporated by reference, uses local image structure and the hyperbolic nature of seismic data is utilized in Radon transform based methods, such as described in for instance Akerberg P., Hampson G., Rickett J., Martin H. and Cole J., 2008. "Simultaneous source separation by sparse radon transform ", 78th Annual International Meeting, SEG, pp. 2801-2805 and Spitz S., Hampson G., and Pica A., 2008. "Simultaneous source separation: a prediction-subtraction approach ", 78th Annual International Meeting, SEG, pp. 2811-2815, which is incorporated by reference.

[0089] In contrast to the above cited work, local image analysis is applied followed by hyperbola fitting to track the reflection of interest. In the local image eigen analysis is performed based on the second moment matrix [as described for instance in Chang et al. 2005] in the common midpoint (CMP) domain of the seismic data. Local structure descriptors are obtained such as orientation, energy, and isotropy that characterize each data point. A simple thresholding on the energy will show the interesting reflections and the interference. Edge linking can be performed based on the orientation to insure trace continuity in the thresholded image. Because the signals of interest have hyperbola patterns, one can fit each detected curve
with a hyperbola and measure the goodness of fit. For the interfering signal or noise, the fitting scores are low. Thus they can be removed from the image.

[0090] In above sections approaches are provided for deblending of seismic shot gathers that allow the use of conventional methods for the subsequent migration process to construct a seismic image. Next, a method is provided that directly uses blended data for migration.
[0091] Preconditioned iterative migration from simultaneous sources using Bregman iteration

[0092] In this section, a method is provided to use blended data directly for migration. The advantage of this alternative approach is that model information can be used as prior information for the deblending process [as described in Berkhout A. J., 2008. "Changing the mindset in seismic data acquisition ", The Leading Edge, v. 27, no. 7, pp. 924-938]. That is, the knowledge about the location of reflectors and the different velocities can help to predict and thus separate contributions from different shots.
[0093] A purpose is to optimize seismic image migration via the following cost functional m = argmin || Lm - Pb \\ +AR(m) (2)

This equation says that one is looking for the optimal image m * that minimizes the least square data fidelity plus the regularization terms. Because the dimensionality of L is very large, Equation (2) is generally solved using an iterative approach.

[0094] In the domain of medical imaging, one is interested in reconstructing a high resolution image with few artifacts. The exact form of Equation (2) is used, with different interpretation that the operator L simulates an imaging process of a medical modality, such as
CT or MRI, rather than a wave propagation process in seismic imaging. Nonetheless, the solution to Equation (2) follows the same mathematical derivation.

[0095] Introducing the Bregman iteration (BI) [Chang et al. 2006] and a preconditioning weighting matrix [Chang et al. 2007], Eq. 2 is reformulated in accordance with an aspect of the present invention as: mk*+l = arg min || W(Lm - Pb - vk) \f2 +AR(m),vk = Pb + vi_1 - Lrnk and v0 = 0. (3)

Here again, m is a trial image; λ is the Lagrange multiplier; b is the measured data vector; W is a weighting matrix that can be optimally designed to accelerate convergence; k is the index for Bregman iteration; the regularization term is implemented as the total variation of m.

[0096] Bregman iteration works as follows. The cost functional (2) is optimized via conjugate gradient (CG) method to obtain m . This is referred to as Bregman iteration 0. The results obtained from Bregman iteration reveal finer details than those from conventional optimization techniques.

[0097] The weighting matrix is derived for near optimal convergence of the data fidelity term, since it is usually the dominant part of the cost functional. With the solution D=W 7W=(Ll i)~1, the data fidelity is expected to converge after the first CG iteration and given any initial image mo.

[0098] In summary: different approaches have been provided herein as one or more aspects of the present invention to address interference in blended seismic shot gathers. The methods can be classified in deblending as preprocessing step and blended data based migration. A first method provides to repeat shot/receiver combinations in different experiments and uses the
resulting mutual shot signatures with MIA to separate the contributions of the different shots. A drawback of such a simple MIA approach is that it does not utilize the structure between signals of neighboring receivers. Thus, the use of coherence parallel in different input domains is provided as a second method in accordance with an aspect of the present invention, i.e., the CSG and CMP domain, to improve coherence based deblending. For layer-separation the use of local image analysis is provided that takes the hyperbolic nature of seismic recordings in the common midpoint domain into account as a third method in accordance with an aspect of the present invention. Finally, Bergman iteration based migration is provided as a method applied directly on the blended seismic shot gathers. It is the intuition that the knowledge of the model, such as location of reflectors and the different velocities, can help to predict and thus separate contributions from different shots.

[0099] The methods as provided herein are, in one embodiment of the present invention, implemented on a system or a computer device. FIG. 9 illustrates a system used in generating and receiving seismic data in accordance with an aspect of the present invention. Seismic signal generators 1700-1702 generate signals which are transmitted into the transmission medium 1708, which may be earth. Some of those signals are reflected back toward for instance the surface of the earth and are received by the seismic signal receivers 1703-1704. The received signals can be stored on a data storage device and processed later by a processor. Alternatively, they can be processed in real time by a processor that is then part of the system. Equipment illustrated in FIG. 9 is known.

[0100] A system illustrated in FIG. 10 and as provided herein is enabled for receiving, processing and generating data. The system is provided with data that can be stored on a memory 1801. Data may be obtained from a sensor or may be provided from a data source. Data may be provided on an input 1806. Such data may be seismic data, which may be
blended seismic data or any other image data. The data can be provided from memory that stores signals generated by the seismic receivers 1703-1704. Alternatively, the data can be collected directly from the seismic receivers 1703 -1704 and processed as received. The processor is also provided or programmed with an instruction set or program executing the methods of the present invention is stored on a memory 1802 and is provided to the processor 1803, which executes the instructions of 1802 to process the data from 1801. Data, such as a seismic image or seismic image representation or any other signal resulting from the processor can be outputted on an output device 1804, which may be a display to display data or a data storage device. The processor also has a communication channel 1807 to receive external data from a communication device and to transmit data to an external device. The system in one embodiment of the present invention has one or more input devices 1805, which may be a keyboard, a mouse or any other device that can generated data to be provided to processor 1803. The processor can be dedicated hardware. However, the processor can also be a CPU or any other computing device that can execute the instructions of 1802. Accordingly, the system as illustrated in FIG. 10 provides a system for data processing resulting from a sensor or any other data source and is enabled to execute the steps of the methods as provided herein as an aspect of the present invention.
[0101] Thus, a system and methods have been described herein for Deblending of Seismic Shot Gathers and for processing blended data into a seismic image without deblending.

claim.claim-text: 1. A method for deb lending seismic data, comprising:

acquiring blended seismic data by a processor in a plurality of recordings from a plurality of sensors, each sensor generating a plurality of blended signals generated by a plurality of semi-simultaneously fired sources, wherein each source is fired more than once; the processor selecting a first source from the plurality of semi-simultaneous sources and a plurality of blended signals received by a first sensor;
the processor arranging recordings of the plurality of blended signals acquired by the first sensor to align with a timing of the first source; and

the processor applying Mutual Interdependence Analysis (MIA) to estimate from at least two aligned blended signals a deblended signal received at the first sensor that is attributed to the first source.
2. The method of claim 1, further comprising:
arranging recordings of a plurality of blended signals acquired by a second sensor to align with the timing of the first source.
3. The method of claim 2, further comprising:
arranging recordings of a plurality of blended signals acquired by the first sensor to align with a timing of a second source.
4. The method of claim 1, further comprising:
generating a seismic image based on the estimated deblended signal.
5. The method of claim 1, wherein the method is applied in oil exploration.
6. The method of claim 1, wherein the method is applied in gas exploration.

8. A method for deb lending blended seismic data, comprising:

acquiring by a processor of blended seismic data in a plurality of recordings from a plurality of sensors, each sensor receiving a blended signal generated by at least a first and a second semi-simultaneous source and the processor recording a plurality of datapoints, each datapoint being associated with a specific sensor at a specific time;

the processor arranging each of the plurality of datapoints in a plurality of transformed recordings in accordance with a timing and a location of each of the plurality of sources in at least one transform domain;

selecting by the processor a datapoint associated with a first time at a first sensor; the processor determining an energy histogram as a result of the first semi-simultaneous source of a plurality of datapoints that neighbor the selected datapoint in the at least one transform domain;

the processor determining an energy histogram as a result of the second semi- simultaneous source of a plurality of datapoints that neighbor the selected datapoint in the at least one transform domain; and

9. The method of claim 8, further comprising:
the processor estimating an energy contribution of the first semi-simultaneous source at the selected datapoint relative to all contributing semi-simultaneous sources.
10. The method of claim 8, further comprising:

the processor selecting at least one datapoint in a neighborhood of the selected datapoint in at least one transform domain to determine an energy contribution of the first semi-simultaneous source to the selected datapoint relative to the second semi-simultaneous source.
11. The method of claim 8, further comprising:

the processor estimating an energy contribution of the first semi-simultaneous source to each of a plurality of datapoints associated with the plurality of sensors relative to all contributing semi-simultaneous sources.

12. The method of claim 10, further comprising displaying estimated energy contribution of the first semi-simultaneous source to each of a plurality of datapoints associated with the first sensor as deblended datapoints.
13. The method of claim 8, wherein an energy contribution of the first and the second semi- simultaneous source is defined by a probability constraint.
14. The method of claim 8, further comprising:

the processor arranging each of the plurality of datapoints in a plurality of transformed recordings in accordance with a timing and a location of each of the plurality of sources in at least one additional transform domain.
15. The method of claim 8, wherein a transform domain is selected from the group consisting of Common Shot Gather, Common Mid Point Gather, Common Offset Gather and Common Detector Gather.
16. The method of claim 8, wherein the method is applied in exploration for natural resources.
17. A method for deb lending blended seismic data, comprising:

acquiring data by a processor of a blended seismic data in a plurality of recordings from a plurality of sensors, each sensor receiving a blended signal generated by a plurality of semi- simultaneous sources;
the processor arranging a recording related to a first sensor in a Common Midpoint
(CMP) domain representation;
the processor detecting an edge in the CMP domain representation by applying a second moment eigen analysis followed by thresholding;
the processor parameterizing the edge by hyperbolic equation fitting; and
the processor estimating a deblended signal received at the first sensor that is attributed to the first source based on a measure of hyperbolic equation fitting of the edge.
18. The method of claim 17, wherein the estimated deblended signal is created by removing data that was determined not to fit a hyperbolic equation.
19. The method of claim 17, further comprising:
generating a seismic image based on the estimated deblended signal.
20. The method of claim 17, wherein the method is applied in exploration for natural resources.
21. A method to create a seismic image from semi-simultaneous sources, comprising:
generating a first plurality of semi-simultaneously generated signals by a first plurality of seismic sources;
receiving the first plurality of semi-simultaneously generated signals by each of a plurality of sensors;
a processor applying an objective function that predicts a measurement by a sensor in the plurality of sensors, wherein the objective function is provided with a sparsity regularization;
the processor minimizing the objective function in an iterative manner against an actual measurement by the sensor; and
the processor generating the seismic image.
